citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Upon inspection, there were several expired drugs (Meloxicam, Metronidazole, and Ponazuril) maintained with other
medications currently in use at the facility for the animals on hand at the facility. The medicated drugs had expired in June
2025.
Expired drugs may have lost their strength and the effect of the drugs may be unpredictable, potentially leading to injury,
illness or death. The facility must not use expired medications and must use appropriate methods to prevent, control,
diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries
Correct by: This incident was corrected during inspection.

During inspection, it was noted that there were two chickens outside of their primary enclosure. The facility representative
reported that the chickens routinely escape from the enclosure during cleaning procedures. Staff were not attempting to
return any of the chickens to their primary enclosure at the time of inspection.
Primary enclosures that do no securely contain birds and lead to bird escapes but birds at a high risk of predation and
injury.
Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they contain the birds securely.
Correct by: This incident was corrected during inspection.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the floor and cage space of the Mexican green conure enclosure needed cleaning. Excreta has
built up in multiple areas especially under the perches, floor and side panels. Staff stated that the areas are cleaned daily,
however, there was excessive waste buildup present during inspection. Regular cleaning is necessary to prevent
excessive accumulation of feces and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests and odors.
Excreta accumulations must be removed from primary enclosures.
Correct by: December 16, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility director.
Additional Inspectors:
ANNETTE CHAPMAN, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Upon inspection, there were several expired drugs (Meloxicam, Metronidazole, and Ponazuril) maintained with other 
medications currently in use at the facility for the animals on hand at the facility. The medicated drugs had expired in June 
2025. 
 
Expired drugs may have lost their strength and the effect of the drugs may be unpredictable, potentially leading to injury, 
illness or death. The facility must not use expired medications and must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, 
diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries 
 
Correct by: This incident was corrected during inspection. 
3.153(a)(1)(iii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
During inspection, it was noted that there were two chickens outside of their primary enclosure. The facility representative 
reported that the chickens routinely escape from the enclosure during cleaning procedures. Staff were not attempting to 
return any of the chickens to their primary enclosure at the time of inspection. 
 
Primary enclosures that do no securely contain birds and lead to bird escapes but birds at a high risk of predation and 
injury. 
 
Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they contain the birds securely. 
 
Correct by: This incident was corrected during inspection. 
3.158(b)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
At the time of inspection, the floor and cage space of the Mexican green conure enclosure needed cleaning. Excreta has 
built up in multiple areas especially under the perches, floor and side panels. Staff stated that the areas are cleaned daily,

however, there was excessive waste buildup present during inspection. Regular cleaning is necessary to prevent 
excessive accumulation of feces and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests and odors.  
Excreta accumulations must be removed from primary enclosures. 
 
Correct by: December 16, 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility director. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
ANNETTE CHAPMAN, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
